justification: The Tools section states: “Self-assessment wisdom scale developed by Webster, J.D… The questionnaire conceptualizes five factors in wisdom…” indicating SAWS is the instrument used to measure overall wisdom.
The same sentence explains that SAWS “conceptualizes five factors in wisdom as Experience, Emotional regulation, Reflection, Humor, and Openness,” linking each sub-construct to the SAWS measure.
construct: Experience (wisdom factor) / Emotional regulation / Reflection / Humor / Openness (wisdom factor)

justification: The article notes: “Action orientation scale developed by McElory and Dowd. The scale measures the action orientation on three dimensions…,” showing that overall action orientation is assessed with this scale.

The same passage specifies that the Action Orientation Scale “measures the action orientation on three dimensions: Preoccupation vs. Disengagement, Hesitation vs. Initiative, and Volatility vs. Persistency,” tying each dimension to the instrument.
construct: Preoccupation vs. Disengagement / Hesitation vs. Initiative / Volatility vs. Persistency

justification: In Tools it is stated: “Share market task by McElroy and Keith Dowd (2007) was used… Participants had to choose between… safe option… risky option,” demonstrating that the Share Market Task operationalizes risky decision-making.
The methodology adds: “After every round of task, a visual analogue of regret on 100 point scale was taken,” indicating regret was quantified with this specific visual analogue scale.
